title: COMP/STAT112 Notebook
text:
Introduction
This is my online notebook for COMP/STAT112 course taken at Macalester College. Please, use the side bar on the left for navigation.
Second day of class. We learned how to render and push the changes to github. Most people in class are very confused.
9/10 Just finished Homework 1 and got it submitted to GitHub. Finally think I got it to work. I am now going to do the reading for class tomorrow and then fill out the survey on the central form.
9/16: Good reminder from this morning’s class: Box plots are constructed from five numbers - the minimum, 25th percentile, median, 75th percentile, and maximum value of a quantitative variable.

title: 3  Activity 03
text:
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors



hikes <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/high_peaks.csv")


#Exercise 1
# a) bar graph
# b) histogram or continuous plot


# Exercise 2
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating))







# error message says cannot find ggplot...this is because I didn't load the packages in this file.


library(tidyverse)


# Exercise 3
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating))









#Exercise 4
# COMMENT on the change in the code and the corresponding change in the plot
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_bar()









# This one labels the x and y axis instead of the generic labels. 
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(x = "Rating", y = "Number of hikes")









# Bars are colored blue
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "blue") +
  labs(x = "Rating", y = "Number of hikes")









# Orange outline around the bars
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_bar(color = "orange", fill = "blue") +
  labs(x = "Rating", y = "Number of hikes")









# Background is white instead of gray
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_bar(color = "orange", fill = "blue")  +
  labs(x = "Rating", y = "Number of hikes") +
  theme_minimal()









# Exercise 5

#Part a
#The '+' is for adding new variables to the plot, for when we need to add "layers".
#Geom is probably short for geometry, so it knows to add a rectangular bar. 
#Labs is to label the axis'
#Color is the outline of the bar and fill is to fill in the color. 

#Part b
#From the bar chart we learned the number of hikes for each rating, easy,moderate, and difficult. 

#Part c
# I don't like the order of the ratings on the x-axis.

title: 4  activity-04.qmd
text:
4.1 4 Bivariate Viz
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(ggplot2)
# Load data
elections <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/election_2020_county.csv")

# Check it out
head(elections)

  state_name state_abbr historical    county_name county_fips total_votes_20
1    Alabama         AL        red Autauga County        1001          27770
2    Alabama         AL        red Baldwin County        1003         109679
3    Alabama         AL        red Barbour County        1005          10518
4    Alabama         AL        red    Bibb County        1007           9595
5    Alabama         AL        red  Blount County        1009          27588
6    Alabama         AL        red Bullock County        1011           4613
  repub_pct_20 dem_pct_20 winner_20 total_votes_16 repub_pct_16 dem_pct_16
1        71.44      27.02     repub          24661        73.44      23.96
2        76.17      22.41     repub          94090        77.35      19.57
3        53.45      45.79     repub          10390        52.27      46.66
4        78.43      20.70     repub           8748        76.97      21.42
5        89.57       9.57     repub          25384        89.85       8.47
6        24.84      74.70       dem           4701        24.23      75.09
  winner_16 total_votes_12 repub_pct_12 dem_pct_12 winner_12 total_population
1     repub          23909        72.63      26.58     repub            54907
2     repub          84988        77.39      21.57     repub           187114
3     repub          11459        48.34      51.25       dem            27321
4     repub           8391        73.07      26.22     repub            22754
5     repub          23980        86.49      12.35     repub            57623
6       dem           5318        23.51      76.31       dem            10746
  percent_white percent_black percent_asian percent_hispanic per_capita_income
1            76            18             1                2             24571
2            83             9             1                4             26766
3            46            46             0                5             16829
4            75            22             0                2             17427
5            88             1             0                8             20730
6            22            71             0                6             18628
  median_rent median_age
1         668       37.5
2         693       41.5
3         382       38.3
4         351       39.4
5         403       39.6
6         276       39.6
#Exercise 0
#Part a 43%
ggplot(elections, aes(x = winner_20)) +
  geom_bar()
#Part b
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_20)) +
  geom_histogram()

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.
#Exercise 1
ggplot(elections, aes(x = repub_pct_16, y = repub_pct_20)) +
  geom_point()
#Exercise 2 
 ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16))







 geom_point()

geom_point: na.rm = FALSE
stat_identity: na.rm = FALSE
position_identity
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point()
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point(shape = 3)
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16, colour = "blue")) +
  geom_point()
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_text(aes(label = state_abbr))
#Exercise 3
#Republican suppport in 2020 and in 2016 appear to have a strong positive relationship. It seems as if Texas tends to deviate from this trend.
#Exercise 4
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth()

`geom_smooth()` using method = 'gam' and formula = 'y ~ s(x, bs = "cs")'
#a)
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_smooth()

`geom_smooth()` using method = 'gam' and formula = 'y ~ s(x, bs = "cs")'
#b)
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
#Exercise 5
ggplot(elections, aes(y = median_rent, x = repub_pct_20)) +
  geom_point()







#This seems to have a slight negative relationship
ggplot(elections, aes(y = median_age, x = repub_pct_20)) +
  geom_point()







#This seems to have a very small positve relationship
#Exercise 6
#This doesn't give a clear picture of how the voter support in 2020 is related to historical votership. You can't really see count very well.
#Exercise 7
ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = historical)) +
  geom_violin()







ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = historical)) +
  geom_boxplot()
